results.expected_answer: Working width (m) x Driving speed (km/h) x Application rate (kg/ha) / 600
results.model_answer:
<think>

The fine application handle allows you to set the dosing openings uniformly. You close two of them to prevent blockages and open the third one further. This setup ensures a good spreading pattern.

The formula mentioned in this section is working width (m) multiplied by driving speed (km/h), then multiplied by the application rate (kg/ha). The result is divided by 600 to get the flowrate in kg/min. So, it's:

Flowrate (kg/min) = (Working Width * Driving Speed * Application Rate) / 600

I should make sure this formula is accurate and matches the context provided. It seems consistent with how other pages calculate flowrates for different granule types.

So, putting it all together, the general formula is as I wrote above.

The general formula to calculate the required flowrate of fertilizer in kg/min is:

\[ \text{Flowrate (kg/min)} = \frac{\text{Working Width (m)} \times \text{Driving Speed (km/h)} \times \text{Application Rate (kg/ha)}}{600} \]

Answer:  
The formula for calculating the required flowrate of fertilizer in kg/min is:

\[ \boxed{\text{Flowrate (kg/min)} = \frac{\text{Working Width (m)} \times \text{Driving Speed (km/h)} \times \text{Application Rate (kg/ha)}}{600}} \]
